"By 1987, in response to a dramatic seasonal depletion of the ozone layer over Antarctica, diplomats in Montreal forged a treaty, the Montreal Protocol, which called for drastic reductions in the production of CFCs. On 2 March 1989, 12 European Community nations agreed to ban the production of all CFCs by the end of the century." It's not about individual change. It's not because a percentage of consumers decided to stop using CFC aerosols that the Ozone hole stopped growing. Governments took action and BANNED CFCs. You can't get them anymore, even if you wanted to. We need to have the same decisiveness today! It's not that individuals are scared of the type of messaging. If you look into global warming and compare the impact of household electricity vs food waste, planned obsolescence, non-green energy production, oil production, the meat industry... There's only so much individual consumers can do. Industry and governments need to change!

One of the important takeaways of this vid is the complexity of climate change.
We CAN'T oversimplify and say, "the REAL issue with climate change is ..." and insert a single issue or bad-guy.
It's a problem with many interconnected issues and we have to be smart enough to treat it as such. Be smart enough to see and tackle it with multiple strategies on multiple levels like geo-political, mass-behavioural, legal, punitive, activist, technical, UX, empirical-analytical, social, media, cultural, educational, awareness, motivational, psychological, etc. that can all reinforce - not compete - with one another. And resist the urge to reduce climate change to a single issue with a single quick-fix that may be easily refuted by others or even oneself.

If you live in Kuwait I could rec you places and shops. - Refuse plastic straws - Bring your own container if unable to finish restaurant food - Use reusable produce bags and totes instead of single- use ones. Frankly, electricity only makes up 20% of our total energy consumption. Sure, we can and should reduce electricity consumption, but a more important question is maybe: how can we convince companies and goverments to switch to renewable energy? Solar & wind energy is already significantly cheaper than burning coal.

However, going back to my first point, our BIGGEST problem is: what do we do with the other 80% of energy use? The use of fossil fuels is embedded in the way we move people and stuff (cars, airplanes, container ships), the things we eat (meat production is a huge contributor to climate change) and the products we use (plastics, concrete or steel for example). For most of these things we still have no clue how to transform these systems to sustainable ones.

We need loads of research & development, and loads of people who are concious of the enormous challenge we're facing. At least that is going in the right direction the last few years. But there's a long road ahead...

I mean I'm from Denmark, a country which as some may know is very active in working against climate change, and I think the Things that worked to get Danes onboard were that we looked at the problem early enough, and a single key source. We started making policies and laws in regards to climate change early enough that the problem seemed relatively fixable in a shorter time period, plus we got kids onboard a short time after, teaching about the dangers and effects of climate change. And while there are a lot of bad stuff, Ice caps and glaciers melting and potentially putting the entire country underwater, and the threat of entire species dying, causing the ecosystem to fall apart. But all of that could be tied down to a single thing. Greenhouse gasses, primarily carbon dioxide of course, which would come from fossil fuels like those used in our cars and power plants. So we saw a way to change it there. If we could switch entirely to green energy consumption, we could potentially save us all from destruction! We already had a head start thanks to investing in wind power following the oil crisis, so that definitely helped make the problem more approachable! Since then other issues have popped out, but we've managed to get by, thanks to focusing on the core things I guess.

Yeah, no. This pseudo-psychological analysis is lazy. People can be motivated to address issues that can concern their survival, and at this point other types of messaging that are more 'hopeful', 'progressive' and 'optimistic' have already been tested. It's time for radical change, and radical messaging. It's not about people reacting to climate news anymore. It's about people themselves realizing this is a core issue in their lives, and starting to get angry and frustrated and hopeless all at the same time about their generation's future. And those emotions are the catalyst we need. Because guess what? People do care today, and people are good at thinking about climate change. It's just a matter of implementing these issues into action and policy-making, and cracking down on the major players that are recklessly ruining whole ecosystems and communities for their own benefit.

@Hg Pb Of course.
@Thomas Maughan If it was black enough to appear only in high concentrations found in areas with large volumes of co2 produced constantly then it would have been dealt with.

@Hg Pb Good thinking; but if CO2 was black the atmosphere would be opaque. It already is, to the wavelengths that CO2 can absorb. But it also re-emits, which means it is both "black" and "white" at the same time. Its warming power is the latency between these; how long can it hold a photon of energy? But most of the time near the surface it transfers the absorbed energy by collision with another molecule and consequently does not radiate. This is an important factor in warming. Conversely, at TOA (Top of Atmosphere), CO2 is free to radiate into space where other atmospheric molecules cannot. The result is CO2 cools the TOA, but warms the BOA (surface). Its actual contribution is rather limited, about 5 percent of the total greenhouse effect, but it is that 5 percent that some think ought to be adjusted.

@Thomas Maughan If co2 was black we would not see very high concentrations normally (slightly darker atmosphere?) but around factories etc producing huge amounts of co2 the sky would be black... people would do something about it...

The ozone hole reforms itself every year over the antarctic for a fairly simple reason and that's lack of sunlight. It is sunlight that bombards oxygen and turns it into ozone.

The video isn't quite right. It suggest that people simply stopped using aerosol spay products and that solved the problem. The truth is that aerosol spray can use totally different propellants than they used to in the 1960s and early 70s. Back then they used CFCs, which some scientist attributed to causing the hole in the ozone layer. Those were banned a LONG time ago. Nowadays all aerosol spray cans use something totally different, usually propane or butane. These types of aerosol spray cans can't possibly do any damage to the ozone layer. So, you can use all the aerosol spray products you want and not be worried one bit that you are going to damage the ozone layer, unless you just happen to have a 60 year old can of hairspay that still works.

I'm glad to see thought being put into how we change behaviors of the public. But, unfortunately, this will not make much difference until we change the VOTING behavior of the public. We need a concerted national effort led by informed and dedicated representatives who are NOT funded by the corporate energy and war industries. We need carbon legislation, national health care, high-speed rail systems, alternative energy projects, and the transformation of our factory-farming system to a more local and sustainable system. We need real representation for all people and true social justice so that all people can see that they have a stake in building a society that is climate friendly and sustainable. Buying a better refrigerator will not get the job done.

It doesn't matter if it's real or not, or if you don't care that it's getting colder or hotter; climate change is a problem because it is connected to about every other environmental problems out there. If you care about pollution, deforestation, or protection of the human health in general you would support solutions towards climate change because those solutions would also solve other problems as well. Cleaner air never hurt anybody, burning fossil fuels does. Also, it's not just using fossil fuels, it's using single use products, especially plastic. Not only does it create tons of waste unable to break down for thousands of years, the process of making it causes carbon emissions, causing air pollution and, whether you believe it or not, climate change. It's not some theory. You want proof? Look at history. London smog. Every country that industrialized early went through the problem of air pollution, and now with regulation it has subsided. Just because you don't feel the direct consequences of it doesn't mean that you can brush it off like it's some fairy tale. You can see it in front of your eyes in countries like China and Korea where micro dust is plaguing on the people. Everyone contributes to the problem, so it's everyone's responsibility to contribute to the solution.

Luke M1A1981X M I know this response is late, but... So, there is a difference between weather and climate. Weather can vary in the short term, whereas climate is a gradual trend. Global warming does not mean that very cold days will just go away immediately and summers will always have days of searing heat. It does mean that those super cold days will gradually happen less and less and winters will grow more mild, and the heat of summer will kick in sooner. Also, natural disasters caused by weather will be more common. Look at 2020- California’s wildfire season has caused two catastrophes, one of which is still going on, Australia had a huge problem with wildfires, the Gulf Coast has been hit with two hurricanes and a tropical storm already this season, with so many storm systems forming that the Weather Service ran out of letters to name them with and had to resort to the Greek alphabet. Did u say *Global WARNING?* There's really no such thing as a *"climate denier",* nor I would suggest a *"climate expert."* Climates are always changing randomly, daily, yearly,and historically. There are far too many highly complex disciplines and unpredictable parameters that effect climate, to be an expert or predict future levels, (as all the dubious computer models have failed to do). As a scientist myself (organic chemistry and biochemistry), *I deal in empirical data.* As such, I 'd say I'm not an expert but a *climate "realist".* I'm not chasing NGO, NASA, or institutional funding to pursue such career, so I dont create a problem, fudge data or propose a solution. To expect "global average" temperature to *NOT* rise or fall by 1 degree or sea levels by one cm or two over 100years is farcical!! That's assuming we can even measure such parameters accurately or meaningfully. Tide gauges for example, are subject to gravity and land movement etc. Earth's temperature varies between ~ -50C and +60C depending on *season, altitude, latitude, sunspot activity, atmospheric moisture, undersea volcanoes, ocean dipoles, tectonic plate movement, deforestation, urban island effects etc etc.* Moreover, the "average" temperature makes little attempt to consider data error or confidence limits, irregular placement of thermometers and accuracy of past empirical data. What really annoys me is when I see a graph with the Y axis showing a range of 1 to 2 degrees. Any small variation will appear to the novice, as an alarming vertical rise when it would be a virtual straight line if the full range of temperatures being measured are expressed.

I'm not downplaying the potential seriousness of drastic climate change, BUT one thing the video fails to mention after drawing a direct comparison to the ozone "crisis". First, chlorofluorocarbons were scientifically proven to be the direct cause of destruction of ozone when radiation breaks up CFCs causing them to release chlorine atoms that steal an oxygen atom from ozone to form chlorine monoxide. This was not a "scientific consensus", this was an empirically proven scientific _fact_. The fact is climate change is another beast entirely. We cannot prove with empirical data the exact cause-and-effect of carbon emissions on the climate model. Therefore, there is a scientific _consensus_. A consensus isn't fact, it's an agreement on an opinion.There's no data that suggests if all carbon emissions suddenly stop the climate will begin to cool. The climate has fluctuated for millions of years without our help. Is carbon emissions a bad thing for the planet? Absolutely. Pollution of any kind is not a great thing. But facts are facts, and we cannot prove with a high confidence % that X directly causes Y in terms of planetary climate. The scale is too massive, and the effort required on a global, multi-national scale to even make a measurable impact in atmospheric carbon levels is so high and expensive it just isn't feasible. To quote the late, great Tupac Shakur--that's just the way it is.

For those without Eumelanin (Black brown skin) the entire Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region makes their health weaken as the area is susceptible to some of the more severe consequences of global warming, including lethal heat waves, extensive drought and rising sea levels.Researchers at Germany's Max Planck Institute for Chemistry and the Cyprus Institute in Nicosia have found that the region – already incredibly hot in the summer – could become so warm that "human habitability is compromised." temperatures could reach dangerous levels for human survivability.for caucasians the threshold is 35 degrees centigrade, for people without melanin's protection against UV radiation this only applies for the most able-bodied people. This means that white people with health problems, children and the elderly have a lower threshold for survivability.The clock is already ticking for those without melanin which is why scientists are spending millions trying to develop artificial melanin for those that can afford it.WHY?...Because global warming is melting the polar icecaps and melting the frozen soil beneath. Until recently, permafrost was not a major concern of climate scientists, because, as the name suggests, it was soil that stayed permanently frozen. But Arctic permafrost contains 1.8 trillion tons of carbon, more than twice as much as is currently suspended in the Earth’s atmosphere. When it thaws and is released, that carbon may evaporate as methane, which is 34 times as powerful a greenhouse-gas warming blanket as carbon dioxide when judged on the timescale of a century; when judged on the timescale of two decades, it is 86 times as powerful. In other words, we have, trapped in Arctic permafrost, twice as much carbon as is currently wrecking the atmosphere of the planet, all of it scheduled to be released at a date that keeps getting moved up, partially in the form of a gas that multiplies its warming power 86 times over.ALL people have melanin, with the exception of albinos - they have genetic mutation that does not allow for melanin synthesis.The difference is the type of melanin produced, mainly eumelanin and pheomelanin. There is also neuromelonin, but this doesn’t show up in physical appearance.
Eumelanin is what constitutes for brown pigments. Dark hair, brown eyes, tan or black skin. That’s the expression of eumelanin, and probably the type of melanin you are most familiar with.
Pheomelanin is what constitutes pink pigments. Red hair, light eyes, pasty and red-hued skin is the expression of a higher presence of pheomelanin. This is more common in people of Caucasian descent.Eumelanin has specific advantages as it is the norm for humans. black skin may enhance the body’s natural immune system and provide better protection against disease than white skin (Mackintosh, 2001). The melanin in dark skin is believed to help enhance the body’s natural ability to combat pathogens (Nosanchuk and Casadevall, 2006; Mackintosh, 2001; Manning et al, 2003).Eumelanin has also been implicated in the maintenance of calcium homeostasis (mechanism by which the body maintains adequate calcium levels) known to be involved with calcium ion regulation in the inner ear, which may improve hearing (Furuta et al, 1998; Norris et al, 2005; Nosanchuk and Casadevall 2003, 2006; William, 2007).melanin as it relates to hearing has also found that skin pigmentation reduces the effects of noise-induced temporary hearing loss. For example, empirical studies have shown that people with more skin pigmentation suffer significantly less temporary hearing loss than those with pale skin (Barrenäs and Lindgren, 1990; Maurer et al, 1999). In addition to this, melanin offers resistance to heat or cold, as well as resistance to the activity of inorganic antimicrobial compounds (Garcia-Rivera and Casadevall, 2001; Rosas and Casadevall, 1997) thus improving natural overall health. Which is why people believe tanning makes you appear healthier!darkly pigmented skin is at substantially lower risk of developing skin cancer than is fair skin (Agar and Young, 2005). In the U.S., Also some forms of skin cancer are “50 times” higher in Caucasians than in African Americans, and African Americans have a 13-fold lower incidence of melanoma than do Caucasians (Tadokoro et al, 2003). Melanin also acts as a free radical scavenger and has been shown to protect against Cryptococcus neoformans; this is a parasite of the central nervous system (Curie & Casadevall, 1994; Mitchell & Perfect, 1995). Interestingly, it is known that Caucasians suffer from heightened rates of many diseases that affect the central nervous system. For example, Huntington’s disease, optic neuritis, Parkinson’s disease, Multiple Sclerosis, PKU (Phenylketonuria), Anencephaly and Spinal bifida (Bates et al, 2002; Okano et al, 1990; Tanner et al, 1996; Nelson et al, 1997; Modi et at, 2001; Kurtzke, 1979; Alan, 2003). While there may not be any ‘direct’ relationship between melanin levels and these particular neurodegenerative conditions, it should be noted that (eu)melanin is believed to protect folate and folic acid (Jablonski and Chaplin, 2000; Branda and Eaton, 1978). These are essential vitamins that are particularly important for neural tube development in the unborn (Vorobey et al, 2006; Jablonski and Chaplin, 2000). Depleted levels of these vitamins are caused by UV light exposure (Vorobey et al, 2006; Lapunzina, 2006; Branda and Eaton, 1978), which Caucasians are particularly susceptible (Jablonski and Chaplin, 2000). Depleted levels of these vitamins have been linked to a variety of different birth defects including ‘spinal bifida’ and ‘anencephaly’ (brain malformation). Research has also shown that melanin is actually not a sunscreen , against UVB radiation but absorbs and utilizes it (Mackintosh, 2001; Hill, 1992; Scheibner et al., 1986).In fact the study of melanin was the basis for breakthroughs in computer science!Lighter skin has less melanin and what is produced is typically found arranged in clusters of melanosomes in keratinocytes, while darker skin has more melanin and the melanosomes are distributed individually in keratinocytes, thus absorbing light more efficiently (Miyamura, 2006).
Caucasian people, while producing overall lower levels of melanin (Tadokoro et al., 2003; Miyamura, 2006), have also been shown to possess higher concentrations of a more deleterious form of melanin known as “Pheomelanin.” The kind of melanin that helps to cause blonde and red hair (blue and green eyes) also increases the potential for cell death! Pheomelanin filters out UV radiation, but it also increases UV harmful effects and causes cell death, particularly when the melanin is the kind found in light hair or skin (Brash et al., 2004; Maresca, 2006). Melanin plays important roles in vision. Norris et al (2005) show that melanin acts like a neutralizing sponge inside cells in the retina to soak up and destroy reactive oxygen species. Reactive oxygen species, or free radicals, which are energized by light, are thought to play a major role in “macular degeneration”, the leading cause of blindness in people over the age of 60. The disorder is more prevalent among whites than among African-Americans (Evans, 2003; Norris et al, 2005; Klein et al, 1999). The disorder is also found in higher frequencies among people with light eyes than people with dark eyes (Nicolas et al, 2003).Although African Americans (6.6%) were found in a longitudinal study to have slightly higher rates of myopia (near sightedness), not significantly different from white Americans (4.4%), Asians were shown to have the highest prevalence (18.5%), followed by Hispanics (13.2%) (Kleinstein et al, 2005). For hyperopia, whites have the highest prevalences (19.3%), followed by Hispanics (12.7%). Asians were shown to have the lowest prevalence of hyperopia (6.3%) and were not significantly different from African Americans (6.4%).

We are gradually making ourselves more efficient, and that is good, but it's not enough to tip the scale. Individual competitions among single citizens may be a grassroots motivation, but the real damage comes from our industries, our products, our materials. There needs to be a greater push to ramp up fuel economy, and rid ourselves of dependency on oil. That means, no gasoline, no plastics, and less fresh water consumption.
I have made a commitment to myself to rid my household of unnecessary plastics. Once a bottle is emptied, I will actively search out eco-friendlier solutions, with better packaging, and less harmful chemicals. It's easy to turn down grocery bags, and plastic razors, disposable cutlery and dishes, and other items that use low grade plastics. I won't use takeout containers unless they're made from recycled fibers. I'm investigating my city's recycling program, and seeing what forms of waste are predominantly making up our landfills. My plan is to get involved with the city council to start asking businesses to invest in biodegradable options for packaging and products to help eliminate waste. Our disposable items are some of the worst designed products imaginable, in terms of material waste to produce them, and the amount of waste involved in throwing them away.
I know people out there think that this is alarmist, and we are putting undue economic pressure on industries to compete for energy conservation and carbon capture, but the way I see it, it's essential to revolutionize our energy sources and infrastructure. It's like having someone argue for the candlestick industry in the age of the incandescent bulb. Why wouldn't we want to upgrade?! A more efficient, cleaner energy source is on the horizon, and it's time we all made the concerted effort to bring that into reality, and start reducing our wasteful tendencies now.

One of the most important means is carbon-14 dating. Because the age determined by the carbon-14 method may be appreciably different from the true age in certain cases, it is customary to refer to such dates in “radiocarbon years.” These dates, obtained from a variety of deposits, form an important framework for Holocene stratigraphy and chronology. The limitations of accuracy of radiocarbon age determinations are expressed as ± a few tens or hundreds of years. In addition to this calculated error, there also is a question of error due to contamination of the material measured. For instance, an ancient peat may contain some younger roots and thus give a falsely “young” age unless it is carefully collected and treated to remove contaminants. Marine shells consist of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), and in certain coastal regions there is upwelling of deep oceanic water that can be 500 to more than 1,000 years old. An “age” from living shells in such an area can suggest that they are already hundreds of years old.

The preceding and substantially longer sequence of alternating glacial and interglacial ages is the Pleistocene Epoch. Because there is nothing to suggest that the Pleistocene has actually ended, certain authorities prefer to extend the Pleistocene up to the present time; this approach tends to ignore humans and their impact, however. The Holocene forms the chronological framework for human history. Archaeologists use it as the time standard against which they trace the development of early civilizations.

One of the reasons that it is difficult for modern scientists to quantify the possible extent in global warming is that accurate climatic data extends back, at best, only about a hundred years. Accordingly, it is difficult to determine whether any data indicating global warming is simply a normal variation in a general downtrend, or a normal variation in generalized warming pattern.

You know, your arrogance will bite you in the ass someday. First lets change the current definition used in this video of Climate change, to actual climate change, not world temperature change. Climate change refers to a climate, a specific area of the world, and it's condition. This definition of climate change is the one we will suppose is correct, which it is, and going by this, I agree climate change is real, the climate of different parts of the world is constantly changing. However, Earth's overall climate has always warmed and cooled, and the 20th century rise in global temperature is within the bounds of natural temperature fluctuations over the past 3,000 years. Although the planet has warmed 1-1.4°F over the 20th century, it is within the +/- 5°F range of the past 3,000 years. A 2003 study by researchers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics found that "many records reveal that the 20th century is probably not the warmest nor a uniquely extreme climatic period of the last millennium." A 2005 study published in Nature found that "high temperatures - similar to those observed in the twentieth century before 1990 - occurred around AD 1000 to 1100" in the Northern Hemisphere. A 2013 study published in Boreas found that summer temperatures during the Roman Empire and Medieval periods were "consistently higher" than temperatures during the 20th century. Did u say *Global WARNING?* There's really no such thing as a *"climate denier",* nor I would suggest a *"climate expert."* Climates are always changing randomly, daily, yearly,and historically. There are far too many highly complex disciplines and unpredictable parameters that effect climate, to be an expert or predict future levels, (as all the dubious computer models have failed to do). As a scientist myself (organic chemistry and biochemistry), *I deal in empirical data.* As such, I 'd say I'm not an expert but a *climate "realist".* I'm not chasing NGO, NASA, or institutional funding to pursue such career, so I dont create a problem, fudge data or propose a solution. To expect "global average" temperature to *NOT* rise or fall by 1 degree or sea levels by one cm or two over 100years is farcical!! That's assuming we can even measure such parameters accurately or meaningfully. Tide gauges for example, are subject to gravity and land movement etc. Earth's temperature varies between ~ -50C and +60C depending on *season, altitude, latitude, sunspot activity, atmospheric moisture, undersea volcanoes, ocean dipoles, tectonic plate movement, deforestation, urban island effects etc etc.* Moreover, the "average" temperature makes little attempt to consider data error or confidence limits, irregular placement of thermometers and accuracy of past empirical data. What really annoys me is when I see a graph with the Y axis showing a range of 1 to 2 degrees. Any small variation will appear to the novice, as an alarming vertical rise when it would be a virtual straight line if the full range of temperatures being measured are expressed.

People don’t think about climate change because it’s very hard to picture from a human scale. When we hear “2 degree increase will be catastrophic” we think that sounds like nothing because on a human scale, it is. But on a global scale, it’s so enormous you can’t picture it correctly. Also terms like “global warming” cause most people to picture everything getting hotter and winters going away. And dispel the term whenever it’s cold. First, climate is not the weather, it will still get cold. Second, global warming means it will get hotter, but not hot enough for a single human to notice, but again, on a global scale, it makes a big difference.

So “global warming” and “climate change” are technically correct terms, but are worded really badly if the goal is to get people to care.

Sea level changes over relatively recent geologic and human history demonstrate that alarmist claims do not withstand scrutiny. Sea levels rose significantly after the last ice age, fell during the Little Ice Age, and have been rising again since the LIA ended around 1850. In fact, Roman Empire and Medieval port cities are now miles from the Mediterranean, because sea levels actually fell during the Little Ice Age.

During the deepest part of the last ice age, known as the Wisconsin, sea levels were about 400 feet lower than at present. As Earth emerged from the Wisconsin some 18,000 years ago and the massive ice sheets started to melt, sea levels began rising. Rapid sea level rise during the “meltwater pulse phase,” about 15,000 years ago, was roughly five meters (16 feet) per century – but then slowed significantly since the Holocene Climate Optimum, about 8,000 years ago.

An important turning point in British history occurred in 1066, when William the Conqueror defeated King Harold II at the Battle of Hastings. Less well-known is that, when William landed, he occupied an old Roman fort now known as Pevensey Castle, which at the time was located on a small island in a harbor on England’s south coast. A draw bridge connected it to the mainland. Pevensey is infamous because unfortunate prisoners were thrown into this “Sea Gate,” so that their bodies would be washed away by the tide. Pevensey Castle is now a mile from the coast – further proof of a much higher sea level fewer than 1000 years ago.

Those rising oceans created new ports for Greek and Roman naval and trade vessels. But today many of those structures and ruins are inland, out in the open, making them popular tourist destinations. How did that happen? The Little Ice Age once again turned substantial ocean water into ice, lowering sea levels, and leaving former ports stranded. Not enough ice has melted since 1850 to make them harbors again. The ancient city of Ephesus was an important port city and commercial hub from the Bronze Age to the Minoan Warm period, and continuing through the Roman Empire. An historic map shows its location right on the sea. But today, in modern-day Turkey, Ephesus is 5 km from the Mediterranean. Some historians erroneously claim “river silting” caused the change, but the real “culprit” was sea level change. Ruins of the old Roman port Ostia Antica, are extremely well preserved – with intact frescoes, maps and plans. Maps from the time show the port located at the mouth of the Tiber River, where it emptied into the Tyrrhenian Sea. The Battle of Ostia in 849, depicted in a painting attributed to Raphael, shows sea level high enough for warships to assemble at the mouth of the Tiber. However, today this modern-day tourist destination is two miles up-river from the mouth of the Tiber. Sea level was significantly higher in the Roman Warm Period than today.

Science is weird like this. Everybody can believe a theory. Accept it as fact. But let one piece of data not fit, and the theory is so much trash on the road. You do descend into name calling at the first little challenge to your ideas. I thought I was talking to another adult. Consider my guestimation of your age and maturity level downgraded a couple of decades. Some of my skepticism, I admit, comes from life experience. I have seen scientific prophets come and go several times in my lifetime, and as prophets go they just weren't very accurate. They spun a good line with numbers and graphs. Each time politicians and enthusiastic supporters would jump on the 'something must be done' bandwagon. Very rarely did their predictions pan out in real world results. Science is a tool and a scientist is only as good as their real world results. From a historical perspective, an atmospheric CO2 concentration of 400 ppm is actually almost scraping the bottom of the barrel. Over the Earth’s history, atmospheric CO2 concentrations have ranged from 180 ppm to 7000 ppm, see Figure 1 below. On that scale we are in fact today barely above the Earth’s record lows. That 400 ppm is actually dangerously low is a fact the alarmists keep avoiding and suppressing. Below 150 ppm, plant-life dies off on a massive scale. The Earth actually came very close to that point many times over the last 2 million years during the ice ages. At the bottom of the last ice age just 20,000 years ago, life on the planet literally teetered on the brink when CO2 fell to a level of just 180 ppm.http://notrickszone.com/2013/05/17/atmospheric-co2-concentrations-at-400-ppm-are-still-dangerously-low-for-life-on-earth/#sthash.L3ATVFrW.dpbs

You are correct, but you have totally misunderstood.  The sun's visible wavelengths of radiation pass easily through the atmosphere and reach Earth. Approximately 51% of this sunlight is absorbed at Earth's surface by the land, water, and vegetation. Some of this energy is emitted back from the Earth's surface in the form of infrared radiation. "Water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, and other trace gases in Earth's atmosphere absorb the longer wavelengths of outgoing infrared radiation from Earth's surface. These gases then emit the infrared radiation in all directions, both outward toward space and downward toward Earth. This process creates a second source of radiation to warm to surface – visible radiation from the sun and infrared radiation from the atmosphere – which causes Earth to be warmer than it otherwise would be. This process is known as the natural greenhouse effect and keeps Earth's average global temperature at approximately 15°C (59°F). If the concentration of greenhouse gases increases, then more infrared radiation will be absorbed and emitted back toward Earth's surface, creating an enhanced or amplified greenhouse effect."

I think a big problem is the scale as it relates to cost and benefits. No one individual, company, organisation, or even nation can do enough to make an appreciable difference to climate change. That means that making changes means sacrificing profits, competitiveness or standard of living for no gain. The problem can only be solved by everyone doing the right thing, but as long as not everyone is doing it, those that are will be disadvantaged compared to those that aren't. Nobody on the macros scale wants to make the first move because addressing climate change only penalises early adopters, with no tangible reward or payoff. Nobody on the micro scale wants to do anything because the results are so insignificant - what's the point of buying that expensive high efficiency washing machine to save a couple tons a year when the factory down the road is pumping out that much every second? As with many things, climate action require huge participation at every level of society to be effective, and either the benefits will be experienced by everyone regardless of participation, or they will not occur at all. That means there is no reason for individual entities to participate beyond altruism, unless forced to or coerced by legislation or artificial economies like carbon trading/taxation.

The fatal flaw with this video is the fact that Vox doesn't state how much of a degree humans are changing the climate. They are not precise with their statements. Yes, the climate is changing, but it is definitely not heading in a catastrophic direction at all. The earth has
experienced countless periods of warming and cooling, and it is a shame that the leftist media are trying to persuade people about a problem that no well-educated person takes seriously.

To give
historical evidence, in the Roman times, the climate was even warmer than it is today (then it gradually cooled down), and it was at least as hot towards the end of the dark ages. Up until now, it is concluded
that global warming is not happening to the magnitude that Bill Nye and
Neil deGrasse Tyson says it is. We are still technically in an ice age
(known as the Pleistocene Ice age, that has been going on since 440,000BC) and the glaciers are still around eroding the landscape. Before this period, the ice caps were nonexistent. (According to Paleontologists)


Furthermore, the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere (since the 1850s)
has been shown to not be correlated to the average temperature of
earth's climate. And it was only a few decades ago that people actually
started to take into account that the earth is warming up. The earth's
temperature only increases 1.5C every century, not identical to the
figures that professional organizations warned us about. Not only is the
data confirming global warming not taken with serious intent, but it
has been confirmed that the climate change researchers tampered with the
data, a fraud move that makes their rationale appear much less
attractive.

If you told me climate change is real, I would
ask, "How much of that climate change is done by humans?" or "Under
which studies confirmed this to be true?". Not a single global warming
researcher can verify these questions without ambiguity nor claim that the
evidence is undeniable.

+Atomsk's Sanakan Okay, I read them over. Really the only bit of information you gave me was the last link. And even with that it didn't show very promising information. The chart had started at around 1850. In fact, I went and researched a while more for charts and information about global temperature history. Yet all the charts seem to start at around the 1800's. Why wouldn't they show information from long before the industrial revolution to emphasize the fact that that is in fact what is causing this? But if you look back at records from long before 1850, they'll show that the earth has constantly undergone time periods of extreme heat and extreme cold. And that was before the industrial revolution. So why would this be any different? I believe we are blaming ourselves for something that is natural to our planet. It is promising information, I will give you that. But charts are dangerous because there are many ways to "manipulate" data on them.

Atomsk's Sanakan No I would believe it was true if I actually saw proof that it was happening. As someone who loves science and everything about it I've learned that you have to doubt everything unless there's proof/an experiment done multiple times to prove the theory/hypothesis. I have yet to see any solid proof. I've lived on the beach for many years. I go into the ocean just about everyday. I can tell you that the ocean level has not risen. There's a giant wooden post that sits right in the edge of the water. The water always stays right at the edge of it at high tide for as long as I can remember

+Chicken Of the Cave *"Until I start seeing actual evidence of this then I won't believe it's true."* You wouldn't believe it was true, even if you were given evidence. That's how denialism works: "It is, however, important not to confuse denialism with genuine scepticism, which is essential for scientific progress. Sceptics are willing to change their minds when confronted with new evidence; deniers are not." http://www.bmj.com/content/341/bmj.c6950.full *"First it was global warming, and then the earth wasn't actually warming so now its climate change."* You fell for an internet myth. potholer54 debunked this myth of your's in his video: "26 -- Science vs. the Feelies" from 12:54 - 14:06 The term "climate change" goes back to before the 1990s. What do you think the "CC" in "IPCC" stands for? The use of the term "climate change" has nothing to do with some evasion by scientists. Instead, "climate change" refers to a broader category of phenomena, that includes global warming. So global warming is a type of climate change, just like canines are a type of mammal. And just like biologists can use terms like "canine" and "mammal" without it being a conspiracy, climate scientists can use terms like "climate change" and "global warming" without it being a conspiracy. *This is all easily researchable.* "Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial [...] Our results indicate that “climate change” has been used more often than global warming in the scientific literature and continues to be the more prevalent term in recent years. There also appears to be no relationship between the greater use of the term “global warming” (relative to climate change ) and higher temperatures. [...] Our analysis therefore leads us to conclude that the claim that the term global warming was abandoned in favor of the term climate change, in response to stalling temperature, is baseless." https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-20161-0_3 *"The climate does in fact change. Everyday actually. Hotter and colder"* Weather is not climate. *"Water temperatures aren't rising though."* Nonsense. Surface warming / ocean warming: "A reassessment of temperature variations and trends from global reanalyses and monthly surface climatological datasets" "Estimating changes in global temperature since the pre-industrial period" "Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus" "Assessing the impact of satellite-based observations in sea surface temperature trends" Ocean warming: “Assessing recent warming using instrumentally homogeneous sea surface temperature records” "Tracking ocean heat uptake during the surface warming hiatus" "A review of global ocean temperature observations: Implications for ocean heat content estimates and climate change" "Unabated planetary warming and its ocean structure since 2006" http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf ["Ocean warming dominates the increase in energy stored in the climate system, accounting for more than 90% of the energy accumulated between 1971 and 2010 (high confidence).[...] On a global scale, the ocean warming is largest near the surface, and the upper 75 m warmed by 0.11 [0.09 to 0.13] °C per decade over the period 1971 to 2010."]

These are the main gasses that warm the earth. Without them the earth would be a frozen ice ball. To much and you get a planet like Venus, 600'c all due to a Co2 atmosphere. The earth temperature increases by 7.5'c for every 1w/m2 increase in SRF. Its the only number we need to know. SRF is (5w/m2) <del>15. The minus 15 is because the earth is further from the sun than Venus. Venus is used as the Zero point as this was the planet chosen to conduct experiments on atmospheric forcing of a planets temperature. Venus SRF is 80w/m2. (80x7'5) +/</del> SWRI) = 600'c Exactly correct. Earth SRF was 4w/m2 (4x7.5) -15 = 15'c Again exactly correct. Earth SRF is now 5w/m2 (5x7'5) -15 = 22.5'c. The earth must now break the laws of physics, chemistry and thermo dynamics for it not to warm by 7.5'c over the next 40 years.

3:35 - stop blabbing about CO2- it's not to blame!! The problem is POTENCY not VOLUME.

CH4 (Methane) is doing 17x more damage than CO2... Though it only makes up ~15% of air pollutants by VOLUME, it warms the atmosphere 85x more than CO2 (~76% of volume). Luckily, Methane decays after a decade or so into CO2. Human activity is responsible for 65% of global CH4 emissions, and our main contributor is LIVESTOCK.

N2O (Nitrous Oxide) is doing 27x more damage than CO2... Though it makes up only ~7% of GHG volume, it warms the atmosphere 298x more than CO2 (i.e. GWP = 298), and it doesn't degrade! Human activity is responsible for 38% of global N2O emissions and our main contributor is FERTILIZER.

*Let's not forget that agriculture covers 40% of the Earth and compliments forest destruction, which are our planet's air filters.

Reduce your meat and dairy intake - save your health, your wallet, and your world!

VeryEvilPettingZoo 1.) GWP #: CH4 oxidizes into CO2 after 12.4 years according to the AR5, hence the 20 year GWP (~85) is higher than CH4's 100 year GWP (28~36). We agree on this… 2.) GHG VOLUME (%): The atmospheric GHG proportionality of CO2 is 76% and for CH4 it is 16% (average highs). Hence, there is 4.75x more CO2 molecules in the atmosphere as CH4. We agreed here also… 3.) GHG VOLUME (PPM): I found that these percent ratios are perhaps misleading, so I tried parts-per notation. CO2 is 400ppm and CH4 is 1.8ppm… This suggests there is ~222x more CO2 in the atmosphere than CH4. Hence the "4.75" we BOTH calculated is perhaps useless. 3.) CALCULATION ***Via ppm volume: 85 / 222 = 0.38 (20 yr CH4 GWP / CO2 to CH4 GHG volume ratio); Total Atmospheric (aka "TA") CH4 is 0.38x less impactful than TA CO2 in a 20 year horizon. You mentioned at the end of your message the IPCC AR5 pg. 14 gave a figure indicating CH4's TA warming effect to be half that of CO2, which seems to confirm this result. *** Via % volume (incorrect?): 85 / 4.75 = 17.89 (20 yr CH4 GWP divided by CO2 to CH4 volume % ratio); TA CH4 is 17.89x more responsible than TA CO2 in a 20 year horizon. I don't know why you divided 36/85 (i.e. 20 yr CH4 GWP / 100 yr)… In combining GHG volume with the GWP on a 20 year horizon, we don't care about the 100 yr CH4 GWP figure. TWO QUESTIONS: • computing for anthropogenic contribution vs. natural (e.g. 97% of TA CO2 is nature made, methane is lower?) • Any comment on Nitrous Oxide?

I'm not a vegetarian, but drastically reduced my meat & dairy consumption for health and environmental reasons. Anyways, please research: - "GHG flow chart" - GHG atmospheric volume proportionality - "GWP chart" (Global Warming Potential) - GHG warming potencies  - "anthropogenic climate change" - human involvement in GHG production - "causes of deforestation" - reasons of deforestation - "attribution of climate change" - a general summary The main agencies providing data are the IPCC (international), EPA (USA), and EEA (Europe). They pretty much all agree; however, the EPA calculates GHG's on a 100 year horizon, despite certain GHG's, like methane, causing the majority of their warming effects in a shorter term.

As you can see here: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/sources-greenhouse-gas-emissions, Electricity and Transportation are much larger sources of greenhouse gas emissions than agriculture, though -- as pointed out by all these trolls -- agriculture is still a large source.

However, greenhouse gas emissions coming from transportation and electricity are far easier to target since we already have enough technology to convert all of our energy grid and transportation sources to clean energy if we just invested in these technologies. Restructuring our agricultural system is certainly a worthwhile goal, but it's -- by far -- not the lowest hanging and juiciest fruit to reduce this problem.

+idontcare80 firstly green energy is not cheaper than fossil fuels, that's just a fact, solar and wind are more than 2X more expensive than fossil fuels. If it was cheaper then everybody would be using it. And why do you think all the richest countries in the world are loaded with oil. Secondly, my point about building a global sea wall was merely a hyperbole, i was signifying that sometimes you have to think outside the box rather than just take the first solution that pops into your head. Here's an example, if you were the president and someone came up to you and said "we have a huge problem on our hands and in order to solve it we are going to have to get rid of all our petrol cars, our coal, oil, natural gas, stop eating meat ect.". you wouldn't say "sure, ok, just do what you got to do". you would ask questions! "how bad is the problem?", "is there evidence to back it up?", "are there other possible solutions?", "how much will it cost?" my underlying point is that we should start acting rationally rather than just taking the first idea that pops into someones head. When making these decisions we need to use facts. No more political hot air, no more media exaggeration making it seem like the world is going to end.

so you come back to me just like every other environmentalist does. With facts? Developing countries can adopt green energy just as easily as we can, solar and wind are both cheaper sources of energy than coal, and they're getting cheaper all of the time. There's also no harm in those countries slowing their development in order to make sure that they're developing in a way that isn't going to drive all of humanity off of a cliff. I didn't dodge anything, I informed you about which option was cheaper. Not only would massively reducing dependence on oil eliminate the cost of military conflicts in the middle east, but it would also save the lives of thousands of American soldiers, save the lives of millions in the middle east, save the lives of tens of thousands of people who die as a result of air pollution in the US, and it would eliminate a major source of funding for terrorist groups. A global sea wall is FAR from being a realistic solution, and it wont do anything to stop the mass extinction event that has already begun... which is very likely to take the vast majority of the human race with it. When combined with storage, solar and wind can supply a huge portion of our electricity, and that electricity can be used to power just about everything, from our cars, to heat pumps for our homes, to industrial processes. Nuclear is also a great option if we nationalize our grid and improve on the model that the French have been using (with great success) for decades. Hydrocarbon fuels for certain kinds of transportation can be produced from captured CO2 with what is normally wasted energy from nuclear power stations. Anyway, one way or the other, someone is paying for something, and I think most people agree that the better option is to try to avoid global catastrophe.

Now, there are some things about Climate change I'd like to say before I start the video, just in case they're not covered. The first is that climate change is not global warming. Global warming is the belief that Earth is heating up, and it most definitely is, but this in itself is natural. Climate change is the belief that humans are speeding up global warming, which is also supported with a good amount of evidence. When I said that global warming is natural, I mean that Earth has spent most of its prehistoric history without any icecaps, and they only appear during ice ages(which we just so happen to be leaving, right now).

tl;dr
- Climate change is human made, global warming is natural.
- Earth doesn't normally have icecaps.

Perhaps, meat, hamburger, steak or even leather. These are all products of the beef animal (or cattle), but there are also many other byproducts. Beef byproducts are the products that we get from beef cattle that might not be quite so obvious. For example, soap is a beef byproduct because it uses beef fat. If you have a beef animal that weigh 1,000 pounds – 640 pounds of the animal will be used for meat products, such as steak, roasts and hamburgers. This means 64% of the animal is used for meat. However, 99% of the cow is utilized for meat and other products. From 1 cow hide you can get 12 basketballs OR 144 baseballs OR 20 footballs OR 18 volleyballs OR 18 soccer balls OR 12 baseball gloves. If you strung 1 year’s worth of hotdogs – end to end – around the world, you would go around the world 16 times! Leather is a very good example of a beef byproduct.  It is made from the cow hide and it is used to make byproducts. Byproducts are a product of the animal that is used as an "ingredient" in other products. There are many foods that are obviously byproducts, such as steak, roasts and hamburgers. Another more obvious product is milk and other dairy products, such as butterand yogurt. Name some food products that come from animals. Meat, beef, beef jerky, hotdogs, lamb chops. These are all direct example of food products, but they may be used in tv dinners and lunchmeats. Did you know that gelatin, what Jello is made from, comes from the connective tissues of the beef animal. So when you eat Jello, you are actually eating an animal byproduct. Other products that contain gelatin might include gum, fruit snacks like gummy bears, and marshmallows. Many medical products are made from animal byproducts. Some products may contain stearic acid that is found in fatty acids, such as in beef cattle. Ointments for burns and first aid creams may contain animal byproducts. Antirejection drugs are used when someone has a heart transplant, liver transplant or even a ligament in your knee to help the body accept the new organ. Animals, such as beef, sheep and swine have remarkable similarities to our own bodies. Insulin is utilized by diabetics. It can be synthetic, which means that is man-made, but it also can come from livestock. There is a sticky part on the bandages that can be made from animal fatty acids since fatty acids are used to make adhesives. Household and office products also may contain beef byproducts. Dog food might include chicken, beef or pork byproducts. Rawhide bones that dogs chew on are made from animal hides. Laundry pre-treatments contains enzymes – a protein found in cattle and sheep. There is a certain kind of china that knick knacks may be made out of that can be made from an animal byproduct – bone china. Bone china is made from the bones. There may be fatty acids from cattle or other animals added to toilet paper to make it soft. What’s on the label of the glue bottle? There is a cow on the label of glue because you can use a cow’s hooves and horns to make glue. Dish soap may contain beef fat that helps make your hands soft. Even film contains the beef product – gelatin - on the coating of the film. Candles may have beef byproducts in them to give them more strength, to help them last longer, and make them more opulent. What would crayons have in them? Probably beef fat, but there is also a kind out now that is made from soybeans. Paintbrushes can be made out of horse hair, but can be made out of the hairs from other animals as well. Sports equipment is often made from animal byproducts. Many professional teams use cowhide footballs. So not all footballs are made of pigskin like many people think. Footballs can be made out of both pig skin and beef skin. Volleyballs can be made from leather, and so can the baseball glove and the outer covering of the baseball. Industrial use – many lubricants and fluids may contain beef fats. Some inks used in printing contain animal fats. High gloss printing might contain animal fats. Industrial cleaners may also include beef byproducts. Grooming – Nail polish remover contain gelatin that helps give your nails strength. Soap, lotions, makeup and lipstick may contain stearic acid, a fatty acid. But not all of them do – as some people are allergic to animal byproducts. Some also contain lanolin which is a sheep byproduct. Shaving cream also contains stearic acid, a fatty acid. Many deodorants contains fatty acids. When people clean their contacts, they use little white tablets called enzymatic cleaners. Enzymes are a protein found in animals. Saddle soap is used on leather shoes and any type of leather product. It helps leather items maintain softness. Travel and transportation. Antifreeze may contain glycerol, an animal byproduct. Hydraulic brake fluid and car wax also may contain animal byproducts.   Highways are made of asphalt and contain a binding agent made from beef byproducts. Tires contain stearic acid which helps tires maintain their elasticity.

+philonetic *"I know, most of you don't get it, because you're stupid."* ... says the AGW denialist who's willfully ignorant of the science on this topic. *"Co2 is noted as being the key factor which increases water vapor, which is the main catalyst for change in temperature."* There are at least 5 reasons why CO2 is more significant for long-term global warming than is water vapor: 1) CO2 absorbs energy at wavelengths missed by water vapor 2) CO2 has a longer atmospheric residence time than does water vapor 3) Atmospheric water vapor levels are more responsive to temperature changes than are atmospheric CO2 levels; that is: CO2 is a non-condensing greenhouse gas, while water vapor is a condensing greenhouse gas 4) There's a robust, long-term correlation between CO2 and temperature 5) At best, water vapor serves as fast feedback that amplifies the warming from factors such as CO2. Clouds that develop from water vapor, can also act as fast positive feedback or as negative feedback, depending on how high those clouds are in the atmosphere. These effects are important, since CO2-induced global warming has augmented atmospheric water vapor levels, as expected, since warmer air can hold more moisture. So atmospheric humidity increased during the recent period of pronounced global warming (from about the late 1970s to the present), with a humidity decrease during the global cooling / temperature stagnation period of ~1940s to the 1970s.

This video may as well be titled "Why some 'experts' are so bad at talking about climate change." We cannot overcome climate change through "behavioral nudges" and trying to change individual and consumer behavior. Significant progress will only be made via putting a price on carbon (i.e. a carbon tax). The responsibility to combat climate change falls much more so on energy companies than on individuals. Energy companies are failing to adequately lead the transition from a carbon-based to a renewable energy-based system. This is where government regulation can, and must, come into play. And this is where individual activism can, and must, come into play. Individuals DO need to act, but in terms of political activism--not in terms of things like using one's electrical appliances less. Individual energy-conserving measures are commendable but ultimately futile in terms of their impact in the grand scheme of things.

Climate change isn't about EVERYTHING getting warmer. In reality, it's only an average of a few degrees difference across the planet. The thing is, this makes everything thrown out of balance. Some places will get much warmer, while others will get much colder; some places will experience decades-long droughts, while others will get record floods, while others get giant hurricanes every year. Imagine a spinning top that starts to slow and begins to wobble unpredictably and wildly all over the place; that is what is going to happen to the climate. So what might be going on is that you're living in an area that will experience an increased cooling. In another 100 years, that area might have winters that last months longer than usual and freeze everything solid. It'll be just as deadly as extreme heat.

Random aside number one, I wish, sincerely, that people were forced to take an undergraduate chemistry class. It would solve so many issues, and you'd have an expert that could address your questions more fully than a science teacher would generally be able to. Environmental chemistry would be better, but that was a third year class when I took mine.

Random aside number two, please remember that the argument "if everyone went vegan the world would..." is not designed to be a catch all to prevent cataclysm. It would undoubtedly work, but that argument is designed to sway those like me (from a ranching background) to eat less meat, to convince a small percentage to switch to veganism permanently (bravo, people make fun that those people mention it too much, well they damn well deserve it), and to show the rest that something as simple as making better food choices can have a massive effect on the world we live in.

One thing most species have in common in relation to the theory of evolution is that they're all adaptive. We humans have lost a lot of our natural instincts, we've grown to become too emotionally attached and deeply fear the experience of the emotions of loss.

Lesser species have no choice, they can't build sophisticated technology so they have to adapt to their environment in order to survive; survival of the fittest.

Us humans however are emotionally compelled to hold on to the things we've got because we do have a choice, we can build sophisticated technologies. So instead of adapting as a species to fit the environment, we now try to adapt the environment to fit us as a species. And that's where the logic has gone wrong.

Climate change on earth is nothing new, it has wiped out hundreds of trillions of life forms, both land and water, and that's totally normal, it's not an evil sin.

We are only here now because somewhere down the line a sub species of ours perished while we continued to live on, so we owe it to our selves to thank climate change for wiping out our brothers and sisters, and allowing us to live successfully in this climate, we owe it gratitude.

So at what point do we say to our selves that climate change is a bad thing? Climate change is a psychological issue, not a scientific one. Humans have just becomes too sentimental and afraid to let go of things that have ran their course.

You know, the ice caps might melt and we might lose polar bears, but the rise in sea levels might make rivers in Africa run with gold and solve drout completely providing water and rich farm lands, saving millions of human lives. But if we try and modify the environment we might prolong drout or perhaps even make if worse, and extend the ongoing suffering of human life.

It's our fault for building cities on the coast lines, we were young and nieve, and we still are.

Rodrigo Mendes Thank you for bringing up your point about the meat industry, for it is true that they too are one of the primary sources of greehhouse gases. Awareness of that fact is simultaneously encouraging and discouraging, because on one hand, by reducing our consumption of meat, especially beef, we can each do our part in redcing our "carbon footprint." Eating less animal meat (or hardly any at all or even none at all) is not only good for the environment, it's good for our bodies. But then, I LOVE the occasional steak, you know? I LOVE chicken and pork and lamb and fish , and frankly, I'm not keen on giving those things up entirely. What's discouraging (besides having to reduce or eliminate all animal meat) is the fact that it's going to be extremely difficult to get a majority of humans to change their eating habits. It's easy enough to buy a car that's fuel-efficient or a fridge that has a great Energy Star rating, but quite another to get people around the world to reduce meat consumption by 90% or 75% or even 50%. And let's not kid ourselves, the meat industry is not going to go quietly into the night. They're going to kick and scream and create adds that will create doubt about meat and its effect on the atmosphere, just as the oil companies do with regards to climate change itself. It's going to be a tough road to hoe. But I'm glad you brought it up. The more we know and the more people get "into the know," the better for all of us in both the immediate and distant future.

An oft-used comparison is that globally, animal agriculture is responsible for a larger proportion of human-caused greenhouse gas emissions (14-18%) than transportation (13.5%). While this is true, transportation is just one of the many sources of human fossil fuel combustion. Electricity and heat generation account for about 25% of global humangreenhouse gas emissions alone. - https://www.skepticalscience.com/how-much-meat-contribute-to-gw.html

I assume you're in high school? Right now it might actually be a bit boring since you're learning the fundamentals, but stick with it. Chemistry really comes alive once you get to Organic chemistry and beyond to Quantum, Physical, Inorganic, and Analytical. Be sure to get a good grasp on molecular orbital theory and periodic trends, and don't worry about memorizing the table or atomic numbers of all of the elements. When you get to college I'd recommend taking a major in either Chemical Engineering/Bioengineering, or one of the subsets of chemistry/biochemistry. You can also go for a general chemistry major, but be aware that you won't go into some of the topics with as much specificity. For now, check out this page, know how to assign charges to molecules using formal charge, get to know how to write electron configurations, and get a good grasp on stoichiometry. The rate laws and molecular kinetics will come in college or AP chemistry if you decide to take it (highly recommended - you'll be able to move right to organic once you graduate), and they involve some calculus. First go here: http://www.chemguide.co.uk/atoms/properties/atomorbs.html Then here: http://www.ch.ic.ac.uk/vchemlib/course/mo_theory/ I don't mean to overload you with information, but I sense that you have an interest in the subject, so I thought I might as well send you some useful links! Some of this stuff is pretty profound if you consider the implications.

there is also deindividuation and the bystander effect in play - on a global scale. people may be moved by messaging when they receive it; but when it comes to participating or actualising personal agency to contribute, they feel their contribution is at best minor or even inconsequential.

two parts to this: 1) in large enough numbers and with concerted effort, households definitely can contribute significantly to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but 2) this requires thousands of households across the world to collaborate in a sustained manner, and their gains could be wiped out by either non-collaborators or increased industrial output - factors completely outside of the participants' control.

while understanding the personal motivations and appealing to human psychology would improve the messaging efforts and lead to some improvement, the larger problem of industrial output and deep-seated habits still remain. should humans cut down on meat consumption? or should the meat industry revolutionise their production methods and manage their GHG output directly? should regulators take bolder steps to control GHG emissions, using both punishments and rewards?

it's probably best if all 3 options are explored simultaneously.

Whenever I hear people talk about "global warming" it reminds of the term "global cooling" I heard from a geology lecture. The professor talked about why he thought "global cooling" is a bigger issue.

If you read about "Geologic temperature record" on wikipedia or some other source, the temperature on Earth cycles up and down in a fairly regular pattern, since like forever. But the recent years (in Earth history scale), the cycle has been broken; it never dipped to a very low point like it was doing for a long long time. Something is holding the temperature high and slowing down the cycle. The fear is that whatever is holding the temperature high (enough for us to survive) won't be holding it forever, and at some point the nature (or whatever is driving the cycle) will make the temperature drop so fast that we won't have enough time to prepare for it, and that could be the end of humanity.

well what about the cows. cows produce so much methane their avarage release of methane a year is 70-120 kg. Methane is a greenhouse gas like carbon dioxide (CO2). But the negative effect on the climate of methane is 23 times higher than the effect of (CO2). according to The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United States (FAO) agriculture is responsible for 18% of the total release of greenhouse gases world-wide.(this is more than the whole transportation sector). Cattle-breeding is taking a major factor for these greenhouse gas emissions according to FAO. Says Henning Steinfeld, Chief of FAO's Livestock Information and Policy Branch and senior author of the report: "Livestock are one of the most significant contributors to today's most serious environmental problems. Urgent action is required to remedy the situation." Livestock now use 30 percent of the earth's entire land surface, mostly permanent pasture but also including 33 percent of the global arable land used to producing feed for livestock, the report notes. As forests are cleared to create new pastures, it is a major driver of deforestation, especially in Latin America where, for example, some 70 percent of former forests in the Amazon have been turned over to grazing.

2764rmouradian: My positions on this are not very fashionable, and i'm not a scientist so you should always take what i say with a grain of salt. But basically i think that we are the major driving force for climate change right now. This seems to be the position of most scientists and ocean and atmosphere studying organizations. As for the should we do anything or what should we do about it question, this is a political issue. I was a big fan of alternative energies but later on i discovered that they all have their flaws. No energy source is perfect. Fossil fuels are an amazing resource and people don't give due credit for their importance in the world we have today. It's just that we overused them. Wind and solar would be the best option to try and mitigate the reducing of use of fossil fuels but i fear it would not be enough to totally replace them. This would mean a change of habits and lifestyle especially in the transportation sector, but this dosn't seem politically, culturally and socially acceptable. So what do we get? Denial on one side, and on the other a belief that some magical solution is just around the corner "free energy, thorium, etc.." while everything stays basically the same. We will keep talking a lot about it, but real change won't come because it would be unconfortable even to the average "global warming believer". The serious predictions about climate change don't mean the end of the world or human extinction even if we burn all fossil fuel reserves, but they will mean that we won't be able to feed billions like in the world we have today. War, famine, disease , political unrest will drive civilization to it's knees before the climate stabilizes by around the 2300s. we will have a very different world. As for the fauna and flora they will suffer immensely because this is very different to the glacial/interglacial pattern of the neogene/quaternary epochs (the last 20 million years), add the other pressures made by humans with land use and chemical polution/deforestation and we get a very smaller range of animals and plants to live with. We humans have this expectation that the Earth should remain static and never change because we have grown used to how things are, but that's not how the Earth works. Climate change, tectonic shifting, changes in the Earth's axial tilt ... all things that will continue to happen no matter what we do. Right now the Earth is slowly shedding it's glaciation, and has been for a very long time. The alternative to that is for the Earth to grow and expand it's glaciation, which would mean the climate is favorable for sending us back into the beginning of a very long ice age. +Nikolaus Not really, it's true that growing plants and burning them is essentially CO2-neutral, but farming Mays, Soy and whatnot for animal feed does output more greenhouse gasses. Tractors require a lot of fuel to drive, plough the earth and harvest the crops. The plants themselves need to be transported to factories that combine them into feed, which in turn gets transported to the animals. Moreover the other negative effects of farming are present as well, i.e. overfertilisation and use of pesticides. On top of that, land use itself is far bigger for animal agriculture than for grains/vegetables since the animals themselves also need a lot of food, so in densely populated areas like Flanders/The Netherlands this is really important to take into account as well.

Animal agriculture sets free carbon that has been incorporated in plant matter months ago, and is part of the normal CO2 circulation. In short, a balance of plant growth and grazing animals alone is carbon net neutral. Yes, if you look at the entire volume the number is huge, but it balances out with the plants grown for feeding the animals in the first place. The only thing that isn't carbon neutral is getting the meat to the consumer and cooking it. The transportation industry sets free CO2 that has been taken out of circulation and scrubbed from the atmosphere millions of years ago.

What I meant was that if people lowered their meat intake to something less wasteful, then that would mean more people could eat less, as opposed to less people eating more. This would not directly affect the growth of the food supply, but rather be a more efficient use of it. Since population (not necessarily fertility, assuming you mean the birthrate) directly correlates to how much food is available, this would cause greater long-term growth, but would still eventually peak, because more people = more food consumption. TL;DR: Theres too many people, and soft-rationing the food supply would only delay the inevitable stagnation.

Bad air quality in urban areas such as China (in the intro of the video) IS NEITHER A CAUSE NOR A CONSEQUENCE OF CLIMATE CHANGE!!! It is a problem of public health which is different.
People living in dense cities concentrate pollution but the denser the city the less people pollute per capita. For example in France, air quality is terrible in Paris compared with rural areas or smaller cities. However people living in Paris actually pollute a lot less on average (they use their individual cars less, live in dense buildings with smaller heat losses etc.). The poor quality of the air is because however parisians on average cause less pollution, their high number in a small area means they have much less air per capita to dilute the pollution they create.

STOP MIXING HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES, it gets everyone confused.

Trying to solve the issue chemically, from the position of the livestock, hasn't been fruitful enough, so that leaves dealing with the psyches and bodily health of billions of omnivores. Weaning large populations off of secondary factors of life is difficult, but doable, because as long as the outcome still leads to access to the same primary factors, it may not even be that noticeable of a difference. This is unfortunately a very political issue and takes political measures.

Methane. A hydrocarbon gas produced both through natural sources and human activities, including the decomposition of wastes in landfills, agriculture, and especially rice cultivation, as well as ruminant digestion and manure management associated with domestic livestock. On a molecule-for-molecule basis, methane is a far more active greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide, but also one which is much less abundant in the atmosphere. https://climate.nasa.gov/causes/ There are many more causes.

I pretty much agree here with cows=methane=not great, therefore less cows=less gas=better. I don't eat beef anymore, because I was eventually found to have an intolerance to a protein in it which had been making me sick. Now, I used to ~love~ a good, medium rare steak, and it was really hard to give it up. But a year on and I don't miss it as much. Since cutting beef out of my diet, I've noticed the stark contrast between the price of beef and the price of the other staple meats. It's stupidly cheap, at least in my region. Compared to say, lamb, a similar quality cut of beef or veal is usually 1/4 to 1/3 of the price per kg, which implies, to me, a surplus of supply. Of course I know there's more of a cow to go around than a sheep or a chicken, but that's also more animal to feed and fart and poop. Considering the impact that we _know_ cows in particular have on both the natural environment and greenhouse emissions, and the sheer amount of resources required to feed and maintain our supply, I feel like we could really stand to make change in this area and see results, not just in methane reduction, but also the availability of arable land that could have its use redirected to providing food to people rather than livestock, since at the moment only a tiny portion of the crops we produce are for people. It doesn't mean we have to cut out all livestock overnight, or even all cows & beef, but by scaling down beef operations by a small amount in each location, we could start the ball rolling towards positive change. Plus it'll make the Veggies happy and less complaining also = better, right?

It's not about veganism and whether humans are meant to eat meat or not. This is about how much destruction mass producing livestock causes. The cows we breed alone produce more than two billion pounds of manure nitrogen per year. Studies can tell you that animal agriculture is the leading factor of polluted waters. You can feed 800 million people with the grain that we feed to livestock. Meat production is responsible for roughly 20% of greenhouse gas emissions. The water we give to these mass produced livestock use half the water consumed in the country (USA). 260 million acres of land is used to produce feed for livestock. This is where veganism comes into play. Yes I agree in the Stone Age and whatnot eating meat was necessary to survive but that's because it was a necessity. Today it is not a necessity. Back then they didn't have supermarkets/grocery stores. Today we do and it carries all the food you can imagine. The amount of harm we are doing to the environment is not worth a burger, bacon, or those "all-you-can-eat" wings. Especially when there's so many other options right in front of you. And if you can't give up those things, try eating plant-based "meat". Similar flavor, minus the harm of the animal and environment :)

Galaxian Studios Well, you are objectively wrong lol. I can't really take anyone seriously who thinks our small teeth are somehow proof of anything when pandas and hippos are both herbivorous.

Our teeth and jaws aren't made for eating meat. Yes, we have the ability to eat meat with our teeth but just because we have canines doesn't automatically make us omnis. 2 issues with the whole canine thing 1. We have only FOUR canines out of 30-something teeth and they aren't even that sharp; you can't cut your finger with them whereas a true carnivore (say a dog or cat) can pierce your skin. And 2. A lot of herbivores have canines, like gorillas, some deer, hippos, and some other animals too; having canines doesn't automatically make us omni/carnivores. Additionally, our jaws can move side to side, whereas a dog, cat, tiger, etc. can only move their jaws up and down. Also, the development of atherosclerotic plaque is another indicator of us being herbivores. Only herbivores can develop plaques in their arteries. Dogs, cats, and animals meant to eat meat never will (unless you remove their thyroid for some reason) develop plaque build up in arterial walls. There are various other indicators like the length of our digestive tracts that indicate we are herbivores, you should look it up.
