+Mytheroo *"and this is why you fail. The argument is CATASTROPHIC ANTHROPOGENIC global warming (CAGW) has not been demonstrated sufficiently"* That's just a straw man you contrarians use to misrepresent mainstream climate science, akin to how many creationists use the phrase "molecules-to-man" to misrepresent evolutionary biology: Another claim advanced by those who reject the mainstream scientific agreement on climate is that the consensus position consists of a claim of catastrophic anthropogenic global warming or the frequently used acronym CAGW [...]. However, CAGW is rarely, if ever, defined or sourced to a mainstream scientific organization or study. Any scientific study’s result, or statement by a researcher, that does not fit a contrarian’s personal, flexible definition of CAGW can therefore be adopted as ostensibly supporting their view and refuting the mainstream, even when such results are actually consistent with the mainstream position on climate [...]. [...] Additionally, we find that *catastrophic anthropogenic global warming* [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a *straw man* used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)." https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-20161-0_3 *"The questions are do humans cause the bulk of this warming and is it catastrophic? The 97% consensus group were not asked that question."* Again, because that's a vague straw man you contrarians made up. There's an evidence-based scientific consensus that: A1) There has been global warming since the mid-20th century. A2) Humans [largely via anthropogenic greenhouse gases] caused most of this recent warming. A3) Most of the recent [or near future] climate change is [or will be] caused by humans. A4) Climate change is a serious problem and/or a danger to humanity. The following sources document the consensus on A1 and A2: Table 1: "Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming" "Does it matter if the consensus on anthropogenic global warming is 97% or 99.99%?" Page 49 of: "Models, manifestation and attribution of climate change" For the consensus on A3 and A4: Among AAAS (American Academy for the Advancement of Science) scientists with relevant expertise (PhD earth scientists current working), there's a *95%* consensus that climate change was a serious problem and a *93%* consensus that recent warming is mostly caused by humans: "Earth Scientists Views on Climate Change" http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/07/23/elaborating-on-the-views-of-aaas-scientists-issue-by-issue/ And in another survey, *~87%* of climate researchers thought that humans caused (or will cause) most of the recent (or near future) climate change, while *~86%* of climate researchers thought that climate change poses a very serious problem and/or a threat to humanity: Figures 88 (v043) and 2 (v007) of: "The Bray and von Storch 5th International Survey of Climate Scientists 2015/2016" https://www.hzg.de/imperia/md/content/hzg/zentrale_einrichtungen/bibliothek/berichte/hzg_reports_2016/hzg_report_2016_2.pdf *"currently the empirical data needs a fudge factor of multiplying what we know by 3 times in order to get the models to create the claimed future change."* If you're talking about positive feedback, then yes, that does applying CO2-induced warming. But not, it's not just a "fudge factor". It includes evidence-based conclusions regarding surface albedo, clouds, water vapor, etc. I discuss that further here: http://blamethenoctambulantjoycean.blogspot.com/2017/09/myth-no-hot-spot-implies-less-global_15.html Climate models actually tend to under-estimate that positive feedback, and thus under-estimate how much global warming will be amplified in the future. For instance: "Climate Sensitivity in the Geologic Past [...] Proxies for CO2 and temperature generally imply high climate sensitivities: ≥3 K per CO2 doubling during ice-free times (fast-feedback sensitivity) and ≥6 K during times with land ice (Earth-system sensitivity). Climate models commonly underpredict the magnitude of climate change and have fast-feedback sensitivities close to 3 K" *"The problem with the science, and the message, is that if you plug in the numbers we have into the models, there is little to no change. They found that the numbers needed to be 3 times bigger to create the effect that was desired, and then set about attempting to explain that this 3 fold increase in the empirical data was valid due to "forcings"."* No. The direct forcing from CO2 yields roughly 1.1K of warming per doubling of CO2. That is amplified by three-fold to ~3K due to *feedbacks,* not forcings. These feedbacks include positive feedback from water vapor, clouds, and reduced surface albedo. These are included in the climate models. For example, see figure 5 of this paper: "Positive feedback in climate: stabilization or runaway, illustrated by a simple experiment" https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/full/10.1175/BAMS-D-14-00022.1

Problem: Burning too much fuel causes global warming, which is bad. Solution: Burn less fuel. Well, if we burn up all our fuel, we won't have any left for airplanes and spaceships, so I'm fine with burning less fuel. And if appliances become more energy efficient then I'll save money on my electric bill, so I gain something from people trying to solve this problem. Because I'm ok with the solution to the problem, I have a rather low bar set for what evidence it takes to convince me that global warming is a thing. But if you told me that the problem were bad enough that I would have to give up fuel entirely all the meanwhile we hadn't replaced it with something else yet, then I would need a lot more evidence before I would be willing to agree that global warming is a real, terrible thing and we should all go back to living in caves without propane or electricity, in order to stop it. Usually I don't go out enough nor pay enough attention when I do go out to remember whether it was hot or cold even yesterday to notice the trends in average temperature where I live, so when I hear people say that the world is warming up, I have to decide whether I believe the person speaking or not, because I certainly don't know from my own experience what's going on in my own locale, let alone worldwide.

Actually China is the biggest producer of greenhouse gases in the world along with developing countries who dont the resources or political stability to use cleaner methods of power production. *Animal Agriculture* contributes about 16% of global greenhouse gas production (GGGP) and *Industrial Processes* contributes around 65% of GGGP. Blake, I don't disagree with any of that. And I'm not sure what I said that you disagree with or think I was wrong about. Yes, raising animals produces CO2 but it's less than energy production- something we can actually fix and people are generally on board with. I don't even want to get into the water consumption because we'll just go off on a tangent, but, yes I am aware of that fact. And, yes, there are more people, cows, pigs, chickens, etc. My point was there were millions of large herd animals prior to global civilization and their presence alone did not significantly tip the scales of the climate; certainly not with the speed we're changing it now in any event. That was in response to someone above claiming that "animals do not create pollution." Bullshit they don't. The difference is how they live that determines the effect of their pollution. Humans and their waste are subject to the same laws and effects. Be wary if hedging your bets on the statement, "If everyone just did X the world would be saved." If everyone just became vegan, if everyone just rode their bike, if everyone turned their lights off all the time, etc. These plans simply do not and cannot work. Any plan that hinges on people being *better* people is doomed to failure. People can be counted on to be selfish, ignorant, argumentative, and resistant to change. Plans to avert society from disaster need to accept that reality and plan accordingly.

That's not true either. In a natural ecosystem, sure, but no one's talking about that. Animal agriculture is incredibly destructive to the environment because *they don't move around*. They stay in one place and food is brought to them while waste keeps being funneled into the same fields of waste. Enormous numbers of animals are bred and raised in the smallest possible space. This is not how animals evolved to live. 40,000 years ago when there were large herds of giant animals pooping all over the place the earth could handle it because herds MOVE. The land was all grass, trees, rock and dirt. There was an ecosystem that could support life and kept a balance. Agriculture as we know it today does not concern itself with the land or the life around it. All it cares about is how to maximize the economic viability of the land and that's a totally different thing.

Rx "...climate change" which was occurring in hot and cold cycles long before humans were around." True, but each time the earth heated or cooled, there was always a reason. Just as there are reasons why it gets hot in the summer and cold in the winter, there are reasons why the earth has heated up at times and cooled down at others. These things don't just "happen" out of the blue, without an underlying cause. In fact, the causes of those past periods of rising and falling temperatures serve to underscore how sensitive the environment is to change. Check out this link. There's lots to explore and find out about. You are not incorrect with regards to "cycles' - they do exist. But what causes those cycles? And can humans have an effect on those cycles or on the earth directly, despite the cycles? Find out for yourself. I'm sure you'll find it interesting. http://ossfoundation.us/projects/environment/global-warming/natural-cycle

Filip Jakacki Sorry to tell you this, but Canada's federal carbon tax hasn't actually gone into effect yet. Perhaps the province you visited might already have fully implemented one, but that's a different story and these taxes are usually designed to be revenue-neutral, in which the money goes toward making low/zero-emission cars cheaper and improving public transport in areas where it's lacking. Also...climate change isn't just everything getting progressively and permanently warmer, which is why it's not 'global warming', and freak weather incidents aren't an indicator of much of anything on a long-term scale. That's why US Senator Jim Inhofe's idea to bring a snowball into Congress as 'proof' that climate change was a hoax made him an utter laughing stock. Today it randomly decided to start snowing here in Vienna after weeks of sun and rain, but that doesn't mean that the oceans aren't dramatically acidifying, sea levels rising and winter ice caps rapidly shrinking. What pollution does have an immediate effect on is the air we breathe and water we drink. Is it not a good idea to reduce our emissions simply for those two, essential things, if not for the longevity of the planet/human race? And electric cars are indeed happenning, espcially in places like Norway (which has very far distances between population centres, I should add), where the (concervative) government is providing heavy incentives for EVs. And considering that the cars are now nearing 300 miles of range (which is wholly adequate--a human can't really go more than that without needing to stop anyway), it's not going to take 30 years to get to 500+ range. That's a bit silly.

Global warming gives people the idea that the whole planet should be warming up at a consistent rate, which just isn't how climate change happens. It leads people to stupid conclusions like "It snowed today, so how can global warming be real?" Or, where I live, "It's been cold in spring, how can global warming be related to this?", nevermind the fact that we've also surpassed the previous record high spring temperature this year. "Climate Change" is more accurate, because "climate" specifically refers to weather conditions over a long time. It also doesn't specify "warming", which is good because, despite warming being the overall trend, some regions will initially become colder as ice melts.

I believe in climate change but doesn't ice increase in size when it freezes? Wouldn't the ocean decrease in size? I'm not trying to prove anything wrong, I'm just curious.

Well, ice is less dense than water, so it expands and floats; the floating prevents the sea level from retreating, because ice which is normally above the surface, not displacing any water, while in ice form, will end up at or below sea level when it melts. That doesn't cause sea level rise though; it balances out, so the seas won't rise from sea-ice melt. The problem is land-ice. Mountain Glaciers and the Ice Sheets of Greenland and Antarctica are normally not displacing any water, but as they melt, the liquid will end up adding to the ocean's total volume, hence, sea level rise.

Oceans will rise as continental (not oceanic) ice caps melt - Antarctica and Greenland being the two big ones. Oceanic ice caps such as the one at the north pole melting will have no immediate impact on sea levels. Oceanic ice caps melting will increase temperatures further through feedback effects, however, due to the fact that ice reflects more sunlight than water.

According to the second law of thermodynamics such a planetary machine can never exist. Nevertheless, in almost all texts of global climatology and in a widespread secondary literature it is taken for granted that such mechanism is real and stands on a firm scientific foundation. In this paper the popular conjecture is analyzed and the underlying physical principles are clarified. By showing that (a) there are no common physical laws between the warming phenomenon in glass houses and the fictitious atmospheric greenhouse effects, (b) there are no calculations to determine an average surface temperature of a planet, (c) the frequently mentioned difference of 33 degrees Celsius is a meaningless number calculated wrongly, (d) the formulas of cavity radiation are used inappropriately, (e) the assumption of a radiative balance is unphysical, (f) thermal conductivity and friction must not be set to zero, the atmospheric greenhouse conjecture is falsified."

That's actually a misconception, based on a graph with a false trend line, that doesn't include satellite data. Also, of the 17 hottest years on record, 16 have occurred in the 21st century (the exception being the strong El Niño year of 1998) (source: https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/2016-was-the-hottest-year-on-record/). Also, most of the warming from Co2 is actually due to the effect after the initial warming (the solubility of Co2 in the oceans decreases after the initial warming). (source: http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v484/n7392/abs/nature10915.html). Also, Volcanoes emit around 0.25GT of Co2 a year, whereas we emit around 30GT (and rising).
